title: Optimized Trajectories for T1 Mapping Acceleration
author: Tamir Shor (Technion – Israel Institute of Technology), Moti Freiman (Technion – Israel Institute of Technology), Chaim Baskin (Ben-Gurion University of the Negev), Alex Bronstein (Technion – Israel Institute of Technology, Institute of Science and Technology, Austria), ...
relevance_why: The use of optimized sampling trajectories and learning methods could potentially inspire similar advancements in audio processing tasks, particularly in audio enhancement or generation.
background: Optimizing non-Cartesian k-space acquisition trajectories in cardiac MRI to accelerate T1 mapping, while ensuring accurate reconstruction of T1 maps from undersampled data.
contribution: This paper introduces T1-PILOT, a method that integrates T1 signal relaxation modeling into the undersampling-reconstruction framework, achieving improved T1 map fidelity at higher acceleration factors.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods used fixed or singular undersampling masks, which limited their ability to adapt to diverse cardiac motion patterns.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work learns per-frame non-Cartesian acquisition trajectories guided by the T1 relaxation model, significantly enhancing quantitative accuracy.

key_innovation: Explicit integration of the T1 signal relaxation model as a constraint during both sampling and reconstruction optimization.
real_world_impact: By enabling faster and more accurate cardiac imaging, this approach could lead to improved diagnostics and treatment monitoring in clinical settings.
limitations: The increased computational demands and the focus on cardiac T1 mapping may limit the applicability to other imaging modalities.

new_terms.T1 mapping: **T1 mapping** is a technique in cardiac MRI that measures T1 relaxation times to assess myocardial tissue properties.
new_terms.non-Cartesian trajectories: **Non-Cartesian trajectories** refer to sampling patterns that do not follow a straight-line path in the frequency domain, allowing for more flexible acquisition strategies.

open_sourcing: Code for reproducing all results will be made publicly available upon publication.
